title: Airbnb Insights: a Visual Analysis
text:
Try the Interactive Tool:
üëâ Launch the Shiny App

 From Data to Destinations: Visual Analysis of European Airbnbs  In this data science research project, we studied European Airbnb listings using a sample of 10 major cities. To support this analysis, we developed an interactive Shiny App that allows users to explore a series of data visualizations examining the factors correlated with price and guest satisfaction.
 For future work, I am developing a predictive model capable of estimating prices for new listings (out-of-sample data) based on features input by the user.
 About the Data  Data was collected approximately four to six weeks before the planned travel dates. Prices reflect the total amount required for the accommodation, including reservation and cleaning fees, for a two-night stay.
 Source: Khemani, D. (2023, March 25). Airbnb Cleaned Europe Dataset. Kaggle.

title: Predicting Airbnb Prices in NYC
text:
In the heart of New York City‚Äôs vibrant and ever-evolving rental landscape, thousands of Airbnb listings compete for attention‚Äîranging from compact studios in Manhattan to sprawling lofts in Brooklyn. These listings differ not just in location, but in amenities, property type, and host features.
 This project takes a closer look at the factors behind Airbnb pricing, focusing on two key questions:

Can we forecast the price of an AirBnb listing based on its features?

What are the discerning characteristics that elevate some listings to a higher price bracket than others?

 To answer these questions, I used statistical modeling and machine learning algorithms‚Äîspecifically, Least Squares Regression and LASSO‚Äîto explore correlations and build predictive models. Drawing from a cleaned dataset of 5,000 listings across NYC‚Äôs five boroughs, I analyzed 23 key variables, such as number of bedrooms, host status, amenities (i.e.: gym, doorman, or TV), and neighborhood group.

üìÑ Report
To learn more about the methods, findings, and visualizations used in this project, view the full report below:

title: A Topic Modeling Analysis
text:
This project was completed as part of my senior capstone in Data Science at Macalester College. My goal was to combine natural language processing, political context, and data storytelling to better understand how migration and diplomacy are framed in Colombian media over time.

Context
Venezuela and Colombia share a complex relationship shaped by decades of migration, conflict, and diplomacy. In recent years, the Venezuelan humanitarian crisis triggered a dramatic reversal in migration patterns: millions of Venezuelans have sought refuge in Colombia. Political tensions and realignments‚Äîlike the 2022 election of Colombia‚Äôs first leftist president, Gustavo Petro‚Äîhave also reshaped the public discourse.


Research Questions

What are the dominant themes in Colombian media coverage of Venezuela‚ÄìColombia relations?

How have these narratives shifted in response to migration trends and political events?



Methods
We collected and analyzed 5,000+ articles from two major Colombian newspapers:
- El Tiempo (center-right)
- El Espectador (left-leaning)
After cleaning and tokenizing the text, we calculated TF-IDF scores to filter out low-importance words and applied Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) to extract dominant topics across articles. Each article was assigned to a topic using gamma scores, and we used multiple metrics to validate the number of topics for interpretability.


What We Found
We uncovered a range of themes, including:
- Migration & Humanitarian Crisis
- Diplomacy and Foreign Policy
- Venezuelan and Colombian Politics
- Security and Guerrilla Groups
- Public Health and COVID-19
- Environmental Degradation
- Migrant Human Trafficking
We also tracked how the frequency of these topics changed over time. For instance, migration reporting surged during 2018‚Äì2020, while diplomatic coverage spiked after Petro‚Äôs election.


Why It Matters
This project highlights how media shapes and reflects national narratives during times of crisis. By using unsupervised learning to trace these patterns, we gained a better understanding of how migration and geopolitics are framed for the public.


ü§ù Collaborators
Nibia Becerra and Emanuel Deleon
View full slides

title: Predicting Life Expectancy: The Effect of Economic Indicators
text:
In this study, my aim was to delve into the intricate relationship between economic indicators and life expectancy, questioning the adequacy of conventional country classifications. Life Expectancy (LE) isn‚Äôt just a measure of healthcare quality; it‚Äôs a multifaceted indicator reflecting a nation‚Äôs economic, social, and environmental status.
Using WHO and UN data, I discovered a positive correlation between a country‚Äôs Income Composition of Resources (ICOR) and life expectancy. Even a small increase in ICOR was associated with a notable rise in life expectancy, challenging the simplistic ‚Äúdeveloped‚Äù versus ‚Äúdeveloping‚Äù country categories.
This study highlights the limitations of relying solely on economic indicators. While developed nations generally exhibit higher life expectancies, some developing countries effectively utilize resources to surpass global life expectancy averages.
It emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach, integrating social, cultural, and political factors alongside economic indicators to grasp life expectancy determinants fully. This work opens pathways for future exploration, urging a broader analysis of non-economic influences and resource utilization for a deeper understanding of global life expectancy dynamics.
Products

Report

title: Genetics Education Site: Making Statistical Genetics Accessible
text:
This site is an interactive resource I designed to explain core concepts in statistical genetics in a clear, approachable way. It covers topics like Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS), and multiple testing corrections‚Äîblending data science, ethical and social context, etc.
Created as a learning reflection exercise, this site is meant for students, researchers, or anyone curious about exploring genetics using statistics and programming tools.

(Visit the website)[https://mariasanchezlinares.github.io/genetics_website.github.io/]

title: A Data Justice Project
text:
Data invisibility is a pressing societal issue. When certain groups are excluded or misrepresented in datasets, it distorts our understanding of social realities and reinforces harmful stereotypes. The underrepresentation of transgender individuals in official statistics is one such gap‚Äîwith real consequences for policy and public perception.
 In this project, I explored two primary research questions:
- What are the key challenges and considerations in accurately representing transgender individuals within official datasets?
- What is the current state of data representation efforts for transgender populations, who is driving these initiatives, and why do they matter?
 My approach involved qualitative research through literature reviews, along with data analysis using R tools focused on SOGI (Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity) variables in U.S. federal surveys.




Bar chart showing SOGI survey inclusion





Key Findings

Self-identification barriers: Fixed-response categories often fail to capture the complexity and fluidity of gender identity.
Privacy risks: Concerns are growing due to evolving legislation that affects LGBTQ+ rights.
Trust gaps: Lack of community involvement can hinder participation and data quality.

 These issues point to a need for more inclusive methods (e.g., write-in responses), robust privacy safeguards, and deeper collaboration with affected communities.



Why It Matters
Driving many of the positive changes in SOGI data collection are civil society organizations and academic researchers, who are leading responsible and ethical initiatives. Collecting comprehensive gender minority data is essential for:

Understanding health and social disparities

Advancing well-being

Developing evidence-based, inclusive public policies




Next Steps
I completed this study as a Research Fellow at the UVA School of Data Science under the guidance of Professor Jess Reia.
The findings from this project will be incorporated into a report for the Center for Global Health Equity at the University of Virginia. I also plan to expand this research by exploring broader datasets and contributing to the global conversation on inclusive data science and SOGI representation.



Products

Slides



Poster

title: Universal School Meals and Student Success
text:
Universal free school meal policies are reshaping how we think about food access and equity in education. In this project, I investigate how these policies impact student performance and engagement in U.S. public schools.
Millions of children in the U.S. experience food insecurity‚Äîparticularly those whose family income is too high to qualify for free lunch, yet too low to afford meals regularly. Universal meal legislation eliminates this barrier by offering free breakfast and lunch to all students, regardless of income.
As of the 2024‚Äì2025 school year, nine states have adopted these programs, including California, Minnesota, and Massachusetts. My research compares these early adopters with other states still following the traditional income-based model.

Research Focus
Using difference-in-differences econometric methods, I assess whether universal free meal programs improved:

Academic proficiency (in ELA, Math, Science)
Student attendance
Enrollment and retention

The goal? To offer new insights into whether this policy actually moves the needle on educational outcomes.


Final Paper
You can read the full research paper here:


This project was completed under the guidance of Professor Amy Damon for my Introduction to Econometrics course.

title: The Highway to Hell: America‚Äôs Interstate System as an Agent of Dampening Social Mobility
text:
Can proximity to interstate highways reduce a person‚Äôs chance of climbing the economic ladder?
This research investigates how living near U.S. highways impacts social mobility, focusing on three key factors:

Air pollution
Job density
Absolute mobility

Using data from major U.S. cities, the study applies multiple regression analysis with data from the Opportunity Atlas and Social Capital Project to assess the relationship between highway proximity and economic outcomes.

Key Findings

Living near highways is linked to lower upward mobility, driven by pollution exposure and reduced access to key resources.
Interstate systems may play a role in perpetuating socioeconomic disparities, rather than bridging opportunity gaps.




ü§ù Research Collaboration
I conducted this study during the PREDOC program under the guidance of Professor Bruich from the Harvard University Department of Economics, in collaboration with Ruhama Baruda, Sarah Hassan, Angela Hilliard, and Cady Ngo.



Project Materials

Full Report 
Research Poster

title: Antimicrobial Susceptibility GWAS Replication
text:
Overview
This project explores key methods from the paper ‚ÄúAdaptation to the cervical environment is associated with increased antibiotic susceptibility in Neisseria gonorrhoeae‚Äù by Ma et al., showing how Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) can help uncover genetic factors linked to antibiotic susceptibility in Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium that causes gonorrhea.


What We Did
To make this research more accessible, we created a dedicated website where we:

Break down the biology and genetics behind N. gonorrhoeae
Explain the GWAS methodology used in the study
Walk through a replication of the paper‚Äôs GWAS focused on azithromycin resistance

While the original paper investigates resistance to three key antibiotics‚Äîazithromycin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone‚Äîand explores how bacterial location within the human body affects evolution, we zoom in on one part of this dataset focusing only on azithromycin.
Our goal is to illustrate how rigorous statistical genetics methods can be applied to pressing public health challenges, while providing a beginner-friendly introduction to microbial GWAS.

üîó Click here to explore the full project website

title: Maria Celeste Sanchez Linares
text:
About me
I‚Äôm a data scientist with a background in economics and a strong interest in interdisciplinary research that brings together statistical thinking and social impact. My academic journey at Macalester College along with a diverse research trajectory sparked a passion for using quantitative tools to explore complex questions. Thus, I have had the opportunity to engage in multiple projects in the areas of education, health equity, economics and finance, media, and even microbial genetics.
Across my work, I‚Äôve found that what excites me most is diving into unfamiliar questions, learning new tools or methods along the way, and finding creative solutions.
